awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: High performance sustainable solution to plastic-based materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to investigate translation of new bioplastic materials as an alternative solution to petroleum-based materials.  The growing environmental concerns regarding the accumulation of microplastics inspires a need for new alternative materials. Petroleum-based products (plastics, fibers such as polyester, nylon, etc.) are notorious for their persistence in the environment because they are not biodegradable when disposed in landfills. From an environmental perspective, it is crucial to develop materials based on cellulose. In addition, cotton is one of the most important cash crops in the United States and most produced cotton fibers go to the textile industry. However, low micronaire (low quality in terms of textile spinning) is a recurring problem and can potentially be applied to other niche markets. 

This I-Corps project is to explore applications of biodegradable materials from cellulose biopolymer derived from low quality cotton fibers. Although considered as waste or discounted for textile applications, these fibers are a premium source of highly crystalline and high-molecular weight cellulose. The technology converts cellulose to a solution and subsequently to commodity products currently produced from petroleum-derived polymers. Proof-of-concept has been demonstrated through producing 3D printed materials, bioplastic films (flexible and stiff), and porous materials.  The ability of this technology to dissolve high molecular weight cellulose (derived from cotton fibers) and its conversion to bioproducts allows preparation of superior performance and versatile cellulose-based bioproducts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The production of commodity products, which can easily biodegrade upon disposal in the environment and substitute the function of currently available synthetic polymer-based products, has been persistently pursued goal among the scientific community. As the most abundant natural non-food biopolymer, cellulose is a good candidate for the preparation of materials similar to plastics, but have a distinctive advantage of being completely biodegradable after use. Through customer discovery and validation, it was learned that there is a critical need for bio-based materials for various industries that can perform the required functions (as packaging or soil cover for growing crops) and biodegrade after use.  This can have beneficial environmental impact and reduces the cost of disposing or and recycling materials. During the Minimum Value Product (MVP) development, several bioplastic samples were prepared from cotton cellulose.  To conduct biodegradation studies, samples were either placed on the top of the soil (to serve as soil cover) or buried in the soil (to test biodegradation when bioplastic films are mulched in the soil after use). Our preliminary results showed that when films were buried in the soil, complete biodegradation occurred around 112 days. However, when films were used as soil cover, no change was noticed until day 102.  The intellectual merit of this project resides in the ability to convert non-food cellulose biopolymer from low grade cotton fiber. Customer interviews and validation indicated the need for a material that can have similar functions compared to synthetic plastics but have a distinct advantage of being biodegradable.  The broader impact resides in the possibility of providing a safe and sustainable solution to plastic accumulation, thus, providing ways to mitigate environmental impacts caused by the accumulation of plastics.
